Over the course of the recession, seven and a half million Americans lost their jobs.
And some were unlucky enough to collect more than one pink slip.
Not only can serial layoffs be devastating in the moment, they can also mar a resume and raise red flags for potential employers.
Minnesota Public Radio's Annie Baxter brings us the story of one couple that knows all of that all too well.
Al and Michelle Ford's great recession started about a year before the official one was declared.
At the end of 2006, word came that the paint-supply company where they both worked was consolidating and reorganizing.
Al had spent 14 years on the manufacturing side of the company, running a paint production line.
Michelle had logged nine years managing customer-service workers.
Within a month of each other, the Fords each got a pink slip.
Michelle panicked.
I thought the world was coming to an end.
I mean, it was just like everything was pulled out from under.
The Fords had been together 20 years and raised two kids.
They now wondered if they'd be able to hold onto their three-bedroom house in St. Paul, and avoid draining their retirement savings.
And though they can joke about it now, hunting for jobs was itself stressful.
It even involved negotiating the use of one corner of their basement.

I think what really matters is how a team responds to that.
